bibl.title: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Philip Showalter Hench, October 9, 1940

div1.p: Kean reports that Reed requested $10,000 to conduct the yellow fever experiments. However, he is uncertain about where the financial records for the yellow fever study are being kept. He discusses an article written by Truby and encourages Hench to contact Thomas M. England, a former yellow fever volunteer.

div1.head: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Philip Showalter Hench, October 9, 1940

opener.dateline:
2804 N STREET, N. W.
GEORGETOWN
WASHINGTON, D. C.
Oct. 9 1940

div1.p:
Your very interesting letter
of the 7th came yesterday by air
mail- I thought that I had told
you that when Major Reed went to
Gen. Wood to get the $10.000 that he had
promised him in the interview that
Reed and I had with Gen. Wood on
Oct. 12, Gen. Wood told Reed that,
as he Reed was only a transient
on duty in Cuba, he would put
the money in my Kean's hands to
be disbursed- This pleased Reed
as he would not have the bother of
it This is I think told in the Belroi address which I sent
you-- Gen- Wood afterwards told me
(I was not at the interview when Wood
said this) that he would arrange
that vouchers should not be required
AC
K
2
because the experiments, it was plan-
ned, should be secret. But the mat-
ter leaked out where the Spanish
immigants were being engaged &
a violent attack on the scheme
was published in the Havana
newspaper La Lucha- So I treated
the matter as a routine disburs-
ment, got receipts for all expendi-
tures and filed my returns with
the Cuban Treasury- They are pro-
bably on file there yet if they have
not been destroyed to make space-
Whether all the records of the Govern-
ment of Intervention were brought
back to the U. S. on were left in
Cuba I am not now certain. It
would be the devil's own job to
find them in either case and
I doubt whether you could show
adequate reasons for asking that it
3
be done- Personally I do not think
it would be worth the trouble- I did
have a little bundle of retained
papers relating to the matter but
where they are now I dont know-
I will take a day off some day
soon and put on some old clothes
and dig around in the old papers
that Mrs Kean has been for
years after me to destroy- Maybe
I will find something to send you
Some 10 or 12 years ago I did come
across them and took out two con-
tracts made by Reed with two of
the Spanish immigrants- These I
had framed & one I gave to the
Army Med. Museum: the other I
hung in my office there as Secy
of the Assn of Military Surgeons.
After I resigned as Secy in 1934 I
4
was not very well and did not go
down to get the last of my belong-
ings for some weeks- When I did
so I found that the office had
been moved across the hall and
this framed document with Reed's
signature and that of Antonio
Benigno (Case 4. p. 75 of our Yellow Fever
Book) had disappeared- Some one
with an eye for relies had carried it
off! The other one is I suppose better
taken care of and is hanging some
where about the Museum- If I can
find any more of these contracts I
will give you one- You ask very natur-
ally why was rent paid for the Rojas
field for a whole year- I dont remember
but I think it must have been that
Reed thought it possible that it might
be needed for additional experiments
the following summer- You remember
5-
2804 N STREET, N. W.
GEORGETOWN
WASHINGTON, D. C.
that there were additional experiments
made by Carroll the next autumn
but with filtered blood and for
these the Camp was not needed-

I read Dr Anglés's letter with
interest. He has a number of errors
in it- It is absurd that the Rojas
Camp was established to test out
the Sanarelli organism- That was
a laboratory proposition and was
completed by Aug. 1st Camp Lazear
was completed on Nov. 20 of that
year 1900- It is an error of small
importance, but it was not Dr. Kean and
his wife who suffered an attack of
yellow fever in the house across the
Street from No. 20 Gen. Lee Street, but
Major and Mrs. Edmunds- I was
living & sleeping in the Hgo building on
6
the Calzada de Marianao (which we called
the Calzada Real) My wife, thank Heaven,
was in New Jersey- I had forgotten
that Dr. Anglés was on the Yellow
Fever Board in Marianao but I
see that Reed names him as one of
them in his Preliminary Note. Capt 2
page 56 of the Y. F. Book-

Would you like for me to write to
him and see if I can put him
straight about the location of
Camp Lazear- It might do some
good- A long letter from Gen.
Truby came by the same mail
delivery with your letter- He said
he had been sick, but that he
had mailed to you the copy of
his article which I had read and
made marginal notes about - only
7.
they were not on the margins but
on the backs of the opposing pages-
He said "they should reach you
by Monday next- Which would
be Oct. 7 as he wrote me Oct. 4-
Did you get my air mail letter as to
Dr. Cooke- And speaking of the Fomites
Volunteers have you ever made any
contact with England? I see a long
review of his services in the Military
Surgeon which has just come. He
retires at the age of 64 at the end of this
month- He remained all this time in the
Army - being an enlisted man until
discharged Feb. 15, 1918 in order to accept
a commission in the National Army-
He has been ever since the World War
an officer of the Medical Administrative
Corps in which they look after Supplies
etc. and have no higher grade than Capt-
ain- His address is Captain Thomas M.
8
England. M. A. C. Governor's Island N. Y. H.
He is a quiet, modest man like Moran
who makes no pose as a hero-

He and Hildebrand occupied Building
No. 1. for the period Jan. 11 to Jan. 31, 1901
see page 85 of Y. F. Book-

I think I have covered all the moot
points in your letter so with all
good wishes
div1.closer:
Sincerely yours J. R. Kean 1. I should not fail however to thank
you for the Sixth Rheumatism Review
reprinted from the Annuals of Internal Med.
Also for your very interesting paper
on the Advantages of Jaundice in
Rheumatic Diseases- I read it
with great pleasure-
2 The discovery of the entries in the Rojas
day book of the payments of rent for
Camp Lazear was great- Hurrah for you!
